ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I got a lot better at reading and writing complicated texts in Russian. The class is centered around reading about 19th-century Russian history (particularly the reign of Nicholas I and Alexander II), and every day for homework we read pretty dense history chapters and wrote summaries. By the end of the course, it felt almost natural to read in Russian without a dictionary, and I felt more comfortable formulating my ideas in writing. There is not a whole lot of speaking practice in this course, other than the presentations, but I still think that my speaking skills improved somewhat over the course of the semester. The course is taught in Russian, and by the end of the course, I could understand about 95% of what Constantine said.
Increased my level of speaking, reading, and writing Russian.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The main strength of the course is Constantine as the instructor; it is evident from the way that he teaches that he is genuinely excited about the material, and he was willing to provide ample assistance outside of class when needed. He really goes above and beyond for his students, and you should take any opportunity that you can to take a class with him. Constantine provides the most in-depth homework feedback out of any professor that I know; if you look at his corrections in-depth, you will really become much better at writing. The only weakness of the course is its routine; every day of the class was more or less the same (which in a way was nice because the workload was predictable and manageable), but by the end of the course, it might have been nice to have a few different activities sprinkled throughout to break up the history readings/discussions.
I think one strength unique to this semester's course the reading component, which was both very interesting and useful.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course had an incredibly organized Canvas page, which was really helpful in navigating the assignments and looking ahead at upcoming work. Constantine really worked hard to get students to participate in class, even though many of the students were pretty zoned out during class, and his efforts to get people to speak up on Zoom must be commended!
I had no issues with online delivery.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you are looking to continue learning Russian. The class is really easy to do well in, and it's a pretty laid-back atmosphere just to keep practicing Russian. Make sure that you like history, though. I thought the history was really interesting (assassinations, attempted revolutions, lots of exciting stuff), but I could imagine that the class might be less enjoyable if you hated history in general.
Yes, if they want to learn Russian.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
